newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Strike threat averted at Nerefco unit.
newsitem.headline: Strike threat averted at Nerefco unit.

text.p: The threat of a strike at Nerefco's Pernis refinery was averted on Saturday after unions and management revised the company's social plan for laid-off workers, the company and unions said.

"The FNV and CNV (unions) together have an agreement in principle and we will put it forward positively to members on Thursday," said Cees Kramer, the leader of the oil-refining division of the FNV Industriebond.
The Pernis refinery in Rotterdam, operated by British Petroleum/Texaco Inc joint venture Nerefco, is due to close in 1999.
The company will expand production at its other Dutch refinery at Europoort, at a cost of 350 million guilders ($204 million), but will still lay off 350 of its 875 employees.
Last week workers rejected the original social plan proposed by the management and some workers staged a brief wild-cat strike of two to three hours.
Kramer said lengthy talks into the early hours of Saturday morning led to the revision of the plan on six points.
Workers will, for example, be allowed to leave the company temporarily to find a new job. If they are unsuccessful after two months, they can return to Nerefco.
However, one sticking point remains. The two sides will meet again around the time Pernis closes in 1999 to revisit the vexed issue of compulsory redundancies.
Nerefco has expressed satisfaction with the revised document.
"In terms of the financial package, there are no changes," said Henk Bosma, Nerefco's manager of human resources.
However, he said the company could not rule out the possibility of compulsory redundancies.
"There should be no need for forced redundancies in four years time, but we can never give that guarantee. What we have given is an assurance that we are not that rigid," Bosma said.
